sn36.5:1.4: Pleasant feeling should be seen as suffering. Painful feeling should be seen as a dart. Neutral feeling should be seen as impermanent.
sn36.5:1.5: When a mendicant has seen these three feelings in this way,
sn36.5:1.6: they’re called a mendicant who sees rightly, has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.
sn36.5:2.1: A mendicant who sees pleasure as pain,
sn36.5:3.4: they’re without defilements in this very life.
sn36.5:3.5: That knowledge master is firm in principle;
sn36.5:3.6: when their body breaks up, they can’t be reckoned.”
